output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of analog electronics, equipping you with the knowledge to analyze and design basic analog circuits. Further exploration in specific areas will build upon this base.
output.introduction: Welcome to Analog Electronics! This course will introduce you to the fundamental concepts of analog circuits, components, and their applications. No prior electronics knowledge is assumed.

chapters.description: What are analog signals? Continuous vs. discrete signals. Examples of analog signals in the real world (temperature, sound, light).
Basic electrical quantities: voltage (potential difference), current (flow of charge), and resistance (opposition to current). Units of measurement (Volts, Amperes, Ohms).
The relationship between voltage, current, and resistance: V = IR. Simple circuit examples using Ohm's Law.
Introduction to resistors. Types of resistors (carbon film, metal film, wirewound). Resistor color codes and tolerance.
Resistors connected in series. Calculating total resistance in a series circuit. Voltage division in a series circuit.
Resistors connected in parallel. Calculating total resistance in a parallel circuit. Current division in a parallel circuit.
Introduction to capacitors. What is capacitance? Units of measurement (Farads). Types of capacitors (ceramic, electrolytic).
How capacitors store and release electrical energy. Time constant (RC). Applications of capacitors (filtering, energy storage).
Calculating total capacitance for series and parallel capacitor configurations.
Introduction to inductors. What is inductance? Units of measurement (Henries). Types of inductors (air core, iron core).
How inductors store energy in a magnetic field. Inductive reactance. Applications of inductors (filtering, energy storage).
Calculating total inductance for series and parallel inductor configurations.
Introduction to diodes. Semiconductor materials (silicon, germanium). P-N junction. Forward and reverse bias.
Diode voltage-current (V-I) characteristics. Forward voltage drop. Reverse leakage current.
Simple diode circuits: rectifiers (half-wave, full-wave). Diode as a switch.
Introduction to BJTs. NPN and PNP transistors. Terminals (base, collector, emitter).
Transistor operating regions (cutoff, active, saturation). Basic transistor biasing.
Using a BJT as a simple electronic switch. Applications of transistor switches.
